title: I need examples of types in use...
content:
Fellow Typophiles,

I am looking for examples of works (posters, book covers, logos...) done with these types:

- gill sans  
- fedra  
- din  
- franklin gothic  
- jenson  
- garamond  
- meta  
- mrs eaves

any help, just a clue, anything which comes off your head will help.

thank you,  
dr

 [‹ indesign question : lines of text surounded by black box](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/typophile.com/node/45462 "Go to previous forum topic") [Using fonts without installing ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/typophile.com/node/30614 "Go to next forum topic")
author: David R

comments.content:
Hi David,

can you narrow that down please? I find it hard to think of anything typographic that would _not_ be covered by this – well, okay, that was an exaggeration.

Time period: of all times — post WWII — digital era — recent?  
Geography/spread: world-wide — US — Europe — local?  
Style/Importance: avant-garde/outstanding — idiosyncratic/representative — anything?

Which Garamond?

General clues for finding typefaces in use:  
 [Search](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/www.typophile.com/node/12344) typophile.com. Most of the faces you need have been asked for before. Like [Meta](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/www.typophile.com/node/42959).

Linotype.com has a pretty neat [in use section](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/www.linotype.com/2106/byalphabet.html)

Especially if you’re looking for images, [searching Flickr](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/www.flickr.com/search/?q=mrs.%20eaves&w=all) (or similar services) has proven helpful, to me. You might try adding ‘font’ or ‘type’ to your query, when searching for short/ambigous terms like ‘Franklin’, ‘Meta’ or ‘DIN’.

F

The Wikipedia pages for some of these have usage details, eg. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gill\_Sans\_Schoolbook](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gill_Sans_Schoolbook "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gill\_Sans\_Schoolbook")

[Museum of Modern Art (NYC)](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/www.moma.org/) for Franklin Gothic  
 [Qwest](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/www.qwest.com/) for Gill Sans  
 [University of St. Thomas](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/www.stthomas.edu/) for Garamond

Dear everyone,

First of all, thank you for your fast answers. I did already have some of these, but not all; this was really helpful.

To answer Florian, I will narrow my request down: contemporary, recent works; US and Europe; anything, from outstanding to common. Any Garamond will do, apart from the crappy Monotype.

Again, thanks to everyone... Keep posting.

dr

Until just recently, <cite>Country Home</cite> magazine used Fedra Serif extensively, beginning with Robert Valentine’s redesign, ca. Sept 2004. However, the latest issue I saw seems to have dropped Fedra in favor of Belizio. Don’t know exactly when that change took place.

— K.

Gill Sans is also used by [Tommy Hilfiger](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/www.shoptommy.com/tommy/) and [Sotheby’s](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/www.sothebys.com/).

Fedra and Fedra Display Serif are used in Modern Painters magazine.  
 [http://www.modernpainters.co.uk/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/www.modernpainters.co.uk/ "http://www.modernpainters.co.uk/")

DIN is used extensively in conjunction with Scala Sans and Serif for info graphics and signage for the Los Angeles Metropolitan Transit Authority. “These seats are reserved for elderly or disabled persons”.  
 [www.mta.net](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748/http:/www.mta.net/ "www.mta.net")

Gill is dominant in Poetry magazine:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011160748im_/http:/typophile.com/files/410K24F60HL_5544._SS500_.jpg)
Fedra Serif B is the text face for <cite>Great Canadian Film Directors</cite>, edited by George Meluyk, published by the University of Alberta Press in 2007.

oh boy, Gill Sans is EVERYWHERE.

Twinning’s tea package has it (oh those british)  
the BBC’s logo (again, british)

See Gill Sans was created in the mid-twenties by a british sculptor, Eric Gill. Once you know a little about the typefaces you’re looking for, you can start to find them where you’d expect.

I know the font on the keys of my keyboard is VAG rounded. I don’t know where to find another example of it, but considering it was made for Volkswagen AG, I can imagine Volkswagen would be a good starting point for my research.

Try to ’meet the type’ as though it’s a child of the creator. You know it’s name, but what’s it’s personality, what’s is nationality. Does it have other brothers and sisters? Cousins? What was it derived from.

Best of luck on your little adventure!  
innovati!
